I'm unsubbing, but not because of the blackout. 

After reading the comments on this thread, I don't want to be associated with people that are truly this empathy deficient.

Maybe you have to also have a degenerative eye condition to understand why people would be upset about the loss of tools for accessibility - to say nothing of the behavior of huffman or the blatant disrespect toward the free labor that runs this place - but I don't believe that to be so.

None of these subs truly believe in their heart of hearts that by shutting down they'll win this battle. But the alternative is to just roll over and not be heard at all. 

No one was truly inconvenienced by r/stephenking being down for a while. It didn't hurt anyone, and it contributed to a cause that is clearly important to a lot of people here, even if it isn't important to *you specifically*. The only "meme" like behavior I've seen around this so far is actually this post talking about  an "after party" and referring to it as an "event".

Done ranting. I've seen some decent people on this sub, but they sure don't seem to be showing up for this thread.

That certainly seems to be what the people who own Reddit expect.

I tend to think that a protest exodus doesn't really work because at the end of the day, people don't *want* to leave.  What they *want* is for the site they're on to work differently.  And at the end of the day, the owners of the site don't really give a shit that you want XYZ feature or capability.  

Your only leverage is your actual willingness to leave and stay gone.

What'll kill reddit is not some half-assed janky site that's drawing people out of protest, but rather a site that people genuinely *want* to use just for its own sake, because it's a cool site that gives them exactly what they want AND it has a critical mass of people.

I remember when Google Plus got started, I actually really liked the user experience there...but almost nobody was using it.  It never attained a critical mass of activity to topple Facebook, so they shut it down, even though it was arguably a way better site.  

I think eventually this is how any of these sites go down: the user experience degrades AND a good alternative starts and develops the critical mass of users to sustain itself.  But that happens not out of some notion of "We gotta show 'em that we won't take it anymore!" and instead out of "Hey, did you hear about XYZ site? It's really great!  Super easy mod tools, terrific experience, etc.  And everyone I know is using it!"
